$PTI: Glad to see secondary canceled in response to our report. Investors are asking management to address our points – selectively disclosed data, missing biomarkers, disappearing trial etc. – before they hand over another $50m

Argument here is similar to Bavarian Nordic, where we correctly predicted Phase 3 failure years in advance based in part on a bad Phase 2 placebo group and a questionable mechanism of action. With an ineffective drug, $PTI is worth cash per share at best ($2) (5/5)

What happened to $PTI's trial of PTI-428 with Kalydeco, which was supposed to read out this quarter? Why don't they talk about it anymore? Why don't they talk about the journal article that shows PTI-428 failing to increase protein levels or channel function? (4/5)

Meanwhile, $PTI data (or lack thereof) shows that the drug doesn't improve sweat chloride. Other endpoints supposedly measured haven't been reported -- why not? CFTR mRNA and protein data thus far are noisy and meaningless, despite company spin (3/5)

$PTI claims its "amplifier" drug for CF improves lung function, but patients on the drug barely improved on average; they only looked good in comparison with an anomalously bad placebo group. A normal placebo group would reveal that the drug is ineffective (2/5)

We're short $PTI. Report available at  https://t.co/zgP1zj7Chp. Stock has run up on unimportant breakthrough-therapy designation, but the underlying clinical data is terrible. The drug is a dud. Conf call 10:30am (866-834-3313), reference Kerrisdale call (1/5)

$PRTA shares slide during management's 11:50am Credit Suisse conference "fireside" chat, as mgmt decides to ignore our report. Stock -10%  https://t.co/rpueni5c9V

PRX002 also showed no positive trend in Ph. 1b despite shotgun approach to endpoints, Ph. 2 is merely longer Ph. 1b & will be no different. We will publish separate report on PRX002. Reasons it does not work likely same as why amyloid-beta mAbs for Alzheimer’s failed $PRTA

Antibody approach to amyloidosis has been tried and has consistently shown zero activity in the heart in radioimaging studies. Even w/o heart-specific issue, antibodies fail to work due to heterogeneity in amyloids, and epitope is blocked/destroyed/degraded $PRTA

$PRTA touts ~50% "best response" rate but this is product of high variance in biomarker being measured (NT-proBNP), not efficacy. Wk-to-wk variance in NT-proBNP is 35%, we expect ~50% of placebo patients to hit a 30% decline one time over 12 months too

Ph. 1/2 results for NEOD001 missing all elements of efficacy — no actual clinical response, no dose response, no improvement over time. Amyloid researchers believe it will fail; coinventors of NEOD001 predecessor & others told us “almost zero” prob of clinical success $PRTA

$ADMS is also a tempting M&A target for other pharma co's. Cutting redundant SG&A & accelerating the sales ramp would deliver add'l upside.
We value core $ADMS at $65/sh. But its pipeline is also undervalued. Assuming 50% prob of success, we see an add'l $37/sh, for >$100 total.
The skeptics are wrong: Gocovri really is better. Patients who switch from generic amantadine to Gocovri greatly improve. It's a good drug.
But $ADMS is heavily shorted (33% of shares, 47% of float) and has a small mkt cap. Skeptics see it as a me-too drug, not a real advance.
In the US alone, Gocovri's addressable market is $3.5 billion. Doesn't take much share to make this a billion-dollar/blockbuster drug.
$ADMS's Gocovri is the only FDA-approved drug for a terrible side effect of Parkinson's treatment, dyskinesia ( https://t.co/I0QfT1cBXc)
